text.tspan: We could, for instance, begin with cleaning up
our language by no longer calling a bug a bug
but by calling it an error. It is much more
honest because it squarely puts the blame where
it belongs, viz. with the programmer who made
the error. The animistic metaphor of the bug
that maliciously sneaked in while the programmer
was not looking is intellectually dishonest as
it disguises that the error is the programmer's
own creation. The nice thing of this simple
change of vocabulary is that it has such a
profound effect: while, before, a program with
only one bug used to be "almost correct",
afterwards a program with an error is just
